awd_titl_txt: Conference: Partnership to Grow Research Capacity in Emerging Research Institutions
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will support an in-person workshop and mentoring activities in support of capacity-building efforts by NSF to enable the participation of minority-serving institutions, community colleges, and two-year and four-year institutions to participate in regional innovation ecosystems.  To support institutions in building collaborations, identifying resources, and preparing competitive grant applications, the activities under this project will connect Emerging Research Institutions (ERIs) with experts in research development and broader impacts work.

Specifically, the project will leverage resources from the Center for Advancing Research Impact in Society (ARIS), Spelman College, and the National Organization of Research Development Professionals (NORDP) to support ERIs as they work through the submission of research capacity-building proposals by establishing relationships among and between ERIs and experts in research development and broader impacts.  The activities will focus on the workshop participants' ability to create partnerships with external organizations to grow in workforce development, research and development, and translation of research to practice.  The proposed partnerships represent a unique opportunity for researchers and administrators at ERIs to join with one another and benefit from the guidance of experts to develop and submit strong collaborative research proposals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The NSF Enabling Partnerships to Increase Innovation Capacity (EPIIC) program supports capacity-building efforts at institutions of higher education interested in growing external partnerships to facilitate participation in their regional innovation ecosystem. The Center for Advancing Research Impact in Society, the NORDP Consultants Program and KnowInnovation partnered on this project to implement a unique and innovative approach to the development of proposals submitted to the EPIIC program.

Based on short,3–4-page preliminary proposals, 50 institutions were invited to participate in this innovative funding model that included three phases of application support: 1) virtual workshops, 2) an in-person workshop, and 3) virtual proposal development support.

The virtual workshops served two purposes: to provide information and to facilitate collaboration. During the virtual sessions, consortia started to tentatively form as applicants began to identify commonalities. 

One hundred-twenty (120) representatives from 50 institutions attended the in-person workshop. The first day of the workshop was focused on finalizing the team arrangements. The second day focused on idea generation among consortia members to mature institutional plans and consortium activities. The final day of the in-person workshop included proposal development, presentations from each consortium about their institutional plans and shared activities and feedback from organizers to strengthen these concepts in preparation for the full proposal.

During the in-person meeting, consortia had access to a Budget Doctor, the EPIIC Toolkit, and Peer Mentors. The Budget Doctor was available to develop rapid feasibility budgets to help institutions determine whether their scope of work was an appropriate size for the budget available. The EPIIC Toolkit, a resource for applicants, included explanations, examples, and sample language that consortia could utilize in the proposal drafting process. Peer mentors provided feedback and guidance based on their firsthand experience.  Each consortium was also assigned a NORDP Consultant to support the development and submission of their proposal. 

Forty-nine institutions completed the submission of their full proposal to the NSF EPIIC solicitation. All  of the institutions that submitted a full proposal in response to the NSF EPIIC program were successful. A publication documenting the innovative process utilized for the EPIIC program was peer-reviewed and published. 


Last Modified: 02/07/2025
Modified by: Susan D Renoe
